trial_identification.studytitle: The importance of progesterone level at day of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) administration on pregnancy rate in the short-term protocol
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Evaluation of relationship between progesterone level at the day of human chorionic gonadotropin administration and pregnancy rate.

conditions.healthcondition: Women with primary idiopatic infertility or miscarriage

interventions.interventions: The ovarian stimulation protocol used has foreseen the intramuscular administration from the first day of the menstrual cycle of Triptorelin 0.1 mg / ml rFSH and until the day of HCG.In all patients was performed by supplementation of the luteal phase progesterone intravaginal 600mg daily

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pregnancy rate. The clinical pregnancy was assessed by the presence of , the clinical pregnancy was assessed by the presence of serum beta-Human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-hCG) positive after 15 days from the oocyte pick up and display of room gestational with or without fetal heartbeat.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At 2 weeks after egg collection for Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients scheduled for IVF-ICSI cycles with an average age of 35 years with basal FSH values <9 mIU/ml and a BMI normal.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: patients with more of 38 years, with basal FSH values >9 mIU/ml and a BMI abnormal.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: In our Center of Reproductive Medicine and Biology "Clinic Center Hera", 80% of patients are subjected to cycles with short-controlled ovarian stimulation protocol. The aim of this prospective study was to evaluate, based on our experience, the impact of elevated serum levels of progesterone in the day of human corionic gonadotropin administration on pregnancy rate.
